title: What will the world look like 50 years from now? What technology will we have, what will the economy be like, and what will the geopolitical organization look like? - Quora

response.answer_text: According to Ray Kurzweil, we'll be post-singularity by 2064, and therefore it's truly unimaginable what technology will change by that time. We may even have the ability to transcend our human bodies and live entirely in the cloud, but that's not to say we will want to do so on any large scale. A few of the safest predictions are: 1. Energy will be far less scarce. Solar is ramping up already in major ways and by 2064 I fully expect that devices like our cellphone PCs will be powered by nothing more than a solar-sensitive outer cover. For large-scale energy usage, Nuclear Fusion and Thorium fission reactors can handle everything else, no oil needed anymore. Battery tech is the only thing that can slow this vision down, but post singularity that shouldn't be a problem either. 2. Robots will be EVERYWHERE.  From ant-sized cleaning robots that wander your kitchen picking up crumbs, to package delivery drones, to guard drones, to pretty much the entire labor workforce of all developed nations, there will be either an AI robot, or a 'driven' robot running on telepresence by some developing-nation driver.  Butlers in your home will become the standard well before 2064, even for the poorest classes of a developed nation. The only question will be "AI or human?" Both options have their strengths and weaknesses, but eventually of course it will all be AI.  The most interesting thing about the robot trend that it will necessarily blur the distinction of being a lifeform byt 2064. Not only will AI be so good that they will have actual creativity and compassion, so we will be able to talk to some of them exactly as we talk to each other today, but most robots will be able to reproduce and die, and of course have their own bank accounts and keep up with their own finances. Bitcoin makes all of that possible right now. 3. Which nations will be the new "1st world" will be is anyones guess... It certainly will no longer be the USA though... The amount of debt our country is currently in alone is bad enough to wipe it off the face of the earth like it's been nuked well before 2064. Perhaps by 2024.   Most likely the richest countries in 2064 will still be the developing BRICS nations of today, but I get the feeling that south america will be the most comfy continent to live on by far. 4. Money & commerce will most certainly all be done on the bitcoin blockchain. Most every form of wealth will be on that blockchain, and it'll touch every single part of our lives. All business documents, healthcare records, ownership records, birth and marriage certificates, everything important will be there, because nothing else on earth is even a fraction as secure as it is on bitcoin's blockchain, nor as accessible.  5. Decentralization will be respected and desired in all things. Governments will still likely exist of course, but their habit of centralizing control over everything will come to an end simply because the trend in decentralization doesn't have any reason to stop with bitcoin and lyft and airbnb... Everything from insurance, air taxis, private police, private law, just about everything that governments and the private sector both do today, can be done in a fully decentralized and open source way that will change the very fabric of our economies and societies in beautiful ways. Corruption and bureaucracy can become words only found in history books. 6. Space travel will be a hotbed of news and entertainment in 2064. Private industry like Planetary Resources gathering minerals from asteroids are a good start, but things will really get rocking when we've got a moonbase that successfully mines the HE3 found up there and we can use that for the perfect fuel to hop around the solar system with. Perhaps even some Interstellar drones will be reporting back by then, but I'd think we'll simply be trying to colonize Mars, Ceres, Jupiter's moons, and Titan by that time and just getting around to doing the first warp-like drive tests. 7. With robots & AI taking most of the jobs, we humans will be freed to do more creative & fun tasks. It may sound scary in today's society for a robot to 'take your job,' but in 2064, it will be a whole different mindset, one where basically everyone is some kind of an entrepreneur and spending the least amount of time working equals the most quality in life.  8. For the extremely lazy or unlucky among us, the Universal Income standard will make sure they aren't truly impoverished, even the potheads that never leave their couches... They can spend their entire lives wasting away playing Halo 17 in complete VR if they want, it won't impact you at all, because you won't be paying taxes towards supporting them. Charity alone will be able to pay a basic income for all of them once we remove the waste in the current, government-run charity systems and replace them with the modern ones that will come along with the adoption of bitcoin. 9. School in particular will become something we cannot imagine yet. Certainly the government-run school systems will be universally seen as the evil indoctrination camps that they are and trends like MOOCs will go a long way towards replacing them. But since the internet will be able to put all information at our fingertips 24/7, even while we sleep, the things we feel we will need to be educated about will change, since the rest all can be accessed in a second on a whim. That might make school much faster and young kids will be walking around with Ph.Ds before long. 10. Medically, we'll have a Renaissance long before 2064. Big Pharma will not be lobbying anything important anymore and actual CURES will start to emerge on the market again, not just pain relievers. A dozen technological breakthroughs in self-monitoring and nanotech are able to vastly improve our life today, but all held back by Big Pharma and FDA legislation for years now. Simply identifying this cause to our suffering is enough to make lifespans double if not far more by 2020, and the new technology that could emerge by 2064 based on those improvements could very well make us immortal or even give us relative superpowers compared to what we can do now! If there is one trend here that all have in common it is that corporatism (governments taking orders from corporations) has held us back in all of these areas and must be eliminated for us to start making process. It is only a matter of time until that happens though; the decentralization movement is already becoming the major human rights issue of this decade and will do more to free mankind than all but a handful of humanity can contemplate yet.

This response will examine the changes I anticipate can be expected 50 years from now. It also will address what I don't think are reasonably likely changes, including specific changes mentioned in some of the other responses to your question. I have an optimistic view of the future in 50 years ; but I don't think it will be nearly as different from the present as some do. For example, I think most of what Luke Parker says in his response to this question, including his selected descriptions of Ray Kurzweil's predictions, will be as funny to us in the future as the the common predictions in 1880 about life in 1950 now seem. I think it will be humorous down the road to see he predicted, for example, robot Butlers! Why will a plastic nineteenth century manservant be desirable, when electronic "smart" appliances will place food, drink, cleaning and communication only a couple of steps and a few button pushes away? Robots will have no value to the future if merely toys. Whatever functions may be robotically performed, there will be no need for artificial men to perform multiple tasks when an entire house will be programmed to meet all major desires of its occupants. Some of Mr. Parker's predictions will likely require many hundreds of years of technological advances. For example, economically-justified mining of asteroids for their minerals. The lack of any current ability to do this, and the extreme cost of space travel, makes that prediction unlikely to come true in that time. The travel cost will exceed the value of the minerals mined, during this century. In 50 years, most of what an average person's daily life consists of will be greatly similar to the present, but with certain changes in the speed and ease of certain tasks resulting from advances in machines, electronic components, and certain systems of distribution of goods and services. The exteriors of most parts of town will be approximately the same, other than for much more digital advertising and far fewer retail stores. And most of our same homes will still be here, but will contain improved wiring, lighting and appliances; and be joined to a worldwide internet at all times. Someone born in the U.S. in year 2000 will still feel very comfortable in that future, and will not feel his/her life has been altered that much, although some of our current behaviors and technology will be obsolete. Most technological advances will be integrated into home construction and improvements, communication, entertainment and security advancements. Most major products (like autos) will still provide the same basic functions but do it more cheaply, safely and dependably. We still won't all have flying cars or personal spacecraft, as it makes no sense to develop goods and support systems that would be so beyond an average individual's budget, inherently unsafe, or need supporting systems so expensive that they exceed our willingness to be taxed to create the necessary custom roadways, air lanes or public transportation. We are extremely unlikely to have any technological achievements in areas where today no scientific explanations for the principles involved even exist, such as anti-gravity propulsion or miniaturized portable fusion power generators. Electric power will certainly be much cheaper, and we probably will invent a better way of distributing it (and internet connections) than we use now. Your question referred to Star Trek style transporters, but these were never more than a writer's imagination, and 50 years goes by like the blink of an eye when a proposed technology has no proven basis in known physical principles, other than the musings that if quantum mechanics theory is true anything is possible. A recent publicized experiment, suggesting transportation of a molecule or atomic particle was observed during an infinitesimally short moment in a laboratory, turned out to be the result of faulty equipment configuration, if I recall correctly. Thought control already exists, if you consider psychotropic drugs, brainwashing interrogation techniques, and the social programming of a generation from birth to believe an official mythology, like is now done in North Korea and has been done for hundreds of years by certain religious institutions I won't mention further here (because I am not interested in a fight with them nor in changing their doctrines or approaches to belief). However, thought control has not yet been shown to be guaranteed effective or capable of predictable results with any individual. My understanding is that attempts to use it have been abandoned as unscientific and of no value by the military, which would have had the most to gain. We just have a rudimentary understanding of the brain now, in 50 years we will know more but the brain is so much more complex than even a quantum computer will be that controlling it like a machine will probably be too complex in 2065. However, we probably will be able to correct certain serious brain illnesses by then with our new knowledge, like chronic depression, schizophrenia, phantom limb disease and other mental disorders we now know are somewhat physically based and involve identifiable groups of brain cells. Weather control would first require a tremendous advance in understanding the totality of the smallest details of earth's weather. Conceivably this could be a project for expected super advanced computers over the next 50 years. Even then it will only extend the time period over which the weather could be forecast, not open the door to significantly and predictably controlling, or changing, the weather. Messing with the weather system even 50 years from now is likely only to screw things up, and maybe even lead to the opposite results than expected. It's probably not worthwhile considering, for many, many years into this millennium. A lot more bang for the buck can be obtained from other scientific endeavors, so you can be pretty sure this won't happen within 50 years, because we don't really need to do much about the weather, other than to try not to screw up the environment and make things worse. Kurweil's prediction of a computer singularity in fifty years was either badly misunderstood or a huckster's promise. Speed of I/O calculations is a very different thing from human judgment and understanding. The only "thinking" the coming faster computers will exhibit is the thinking a programer did while writing the program the computer executes. The computer still will be only calculating probabilities, then moving some machine's switch to off or on. No awareness, ethics or sensations will exist within the computer. There will be only the illusion of electronic thinking, created by a programmer. Remember that Kurzweil and some other futurist authors had a tremendous personal interest in marketing themselves, selling their “expertise,” or in some cases getting others to invest in stock certificates which they have hinted would give people shares in the assumed profit from selling "thinking computers" and their software. Much less likely in 50 years than even a thinking computer, is the ability to take a living person's consciousness (whatever that is, we don't even know this today) and then transferring it into a computer. That's laughable to expect to happen within thousands of years, if ever. Of course, a clever computer programmer may someday program a computer to appear to be speaking for a person supposedly uploaded into it. Once unmasked, that programmer will probably be sued for fraud, but it will be easy to fool many people. Mr. Parker's prediction regarding Bitcoins replacing current national currencies has already been proven absurd - by the fraud revealed this year to have been perpetrated by private, authorized bitcoin registries and the resulting instability of that currency. If the U.S. government can't keep its employees' financial secrets confidential from foreign hackers, don't expect banks and major financial players to risk everything on a privately created currency (Bitcoin) maintained in computers controlled by multiple, independent private companies around the world without any significant legal or regulatory control or supervision. In 50 years it probably will be that physical currency won't be in use. However you can be pretty sure that it will be the U.S. and Europe which control the digital money marketplace; because only they will have an over-riding interest in keeping the system as honest and neutral as possible so they don't lose the huge financial advantage of controlling the world's currency. China simply does not have a financially sophisticated legal system or the government checks and balances to avoid huge amounts of corrupt manipulation; take a look at its current stockmarket scandal and collapse of China's stock market a few weeks ago, bankrupting hundreds of thousands of Chinese investors. Those Chinese investors, and others worldwide, will put their money in U.S. currency, the euro, and U.S. and London stocks next time they have money to invest. That's because they value stability so highly. Incidentally, because of the strong future of the U.S. Dollar, paying off U.S. debt by our government will take little more than printing more Federal Reserve Notes to back its T Bills. A common mistake of futurists is to project the trends of the present too far, resulting in hugely erroneous conclusions. Present trends like elimination of government regulation of business, medical monopolies via patent extensions, and financial benefits to the wealthy at the expense of the middle class, when examined historically over hundreds of years, only reflect oscillating changes which reverse themselves by the growing power of opposition increasing over time, with the pendulum swinging the other way after the need for correction becomes obvious to enough of the population (at least in a Democratic Republic). The legal rulings, congressional actions and public calls for change will kick in in the U.S. and Europe and those abuses will be rectified. As for 50 years from now, the only safe prediction is that whatever the trends then will be, politically, legally and economic, they will be different from the present. As to life expectancy, although antibiotics and scientific understanding of anatomic processes and germ theory extended average life expectancy tremendously during the first half of the 20th Century, during the time since then much less time has been added to the average human life. Most recent improvements in life expectancy were caused by improvement in economic circumstances of our poorest populations, better and faster medical diagnosis, elimination of certain environmental and cultural dangers like standing swamp water, widespread smoking and unsafe vehicles and roadways. Most of the easy fixes have been implemented. Although understanding of the human genome may prove to be a boon to medicine, there still seems to be a natural life limit of 100 to 110 years. A breakthrough on that limit is pure speculation right now, sad to say. Major extension of that limit could come, but it may also prove elusive for hundreds of years. We just don't know. Internet shopping and coordinated low expense delivery will affect a huge elimination of retail distributions of goods and provision of services during the next 50 years, much more than we see today. Very few brick and mortar stores will still exist, and the revamped "stores" that do survive will exist primarily as meeting places for assistance in selection of products with explanations of their operation; and for interaction between prospective and current purchasers to discuss the products and enjoy the social exchanges resulting from such cooperation and discussion. The online sales model will be extended to perishables like groceries, with quality guaranteed. It will also be permanently in place for sale of all matter of professional services, such as attorneys, repairmen (who will diagnose and repair many problems online), pharmacies, physicians (with online diagnoses and recommended treatments), realtors and more. The need for many extended hospital stays will be eliminated by online monitoring, nursing supervision, physician consultations and similar electronically controlled home care. Another potential change will be elimination of many functions currently served by prisons. Those awaiting trial (and presumed innocent) will no longer need be confined in centralized jails. Even convicted prisoners, if sentenced for non-violent offenses and not deemed a social threat, can be ordered to remain home under electronic video supervision and interactive surveillance, assisted with GPS monitors securely affixed to the detainees, instead of jailed at public expense. This should make reformation more likely. The Court will maintain close supervision and adherence to a schedule of training and counseling, through its electronic jailers. This should be at least as effective as the sentences served in current prisons. The home-confined inmates will be subject to immediate police response and sanctions in event of attempts to flee their confinement, or other violation of their "supervisor's" instructions or rules. Furthermore, this will avoid the "hardening" of such inmates through contact with lifetime criminals, eliminate present-day threats of physical injury from hardcore or mentally deranged prisoners, and remove young offenders from the present prison gang culture that forces conformance with the rules of criminal ringleaders. In law enforcement and the criminal justice system, video surveillance and new electronic controls will save the public money, and provide safety and security. I have tried to touch upon the particular points discussed by the question’s original wording and question a few of the predictions in other answers provided by other Quora writers. I am certain that I have overlooked areas which a person in 2065 may consider to be far greater changes than those I discuss here, changes I could not foresee in 2015. But I am fairly sure a large number of the daily preoccupations of 2015’s men and women will remain the same preoccupations of the people in 2065; and that the general environment seen when traversing the neighborhoods surrounding most residential areas in the USA will be amazingly similar to today’s, with some archaic elements removed and some new features added. I don’t expect I will be alive to actually see it, but I wish I could somehow be there then, in good health. I don’t expect the apocalypse, any collapse of the American way of life, or any zombie attacks; instead mankind will probably experience an incremental improvement in education, health, knowledge, morality and independent thought and communication, and there will be cause for optimism for those with realistic assessments of humanity’s past.

Let's look at possible extreme scenarios 1) Extreme technology : Ray Kurzweils Singularity, where artificial intelligences are smarter than the sum total of humanity and all intelligences merge and morph in a virtual space. The actual thing is going to be more "average" in my reckoning. Here are the things that will come to pass in another 50 years for sure. People have always been intrigued of what the future will look like. The answers are quite simple and here you have them for the next 50 years. How can we know what the future will look like? To be able to understand the future, you must know the past. What has taken us to where we are today and what has changed along the way. The world has changed a lot in the last 150 years, but we humans are driven by the same basic needs as we were 150 years ago, food, sleep, sex, the feeling of being appreciated and loved. Will this change in the next 150 years? No. What inventions have really made a difference in the last 150 years? If you take away all gadgets that people in some part of the world are using for entertainment, the inventions that have affected most people around the world for everyday living are the telephone, electricity, radio, television, computer, the car and the ability to communicate through Internet. I think this question needs an answer that isn't so pessimistic, nihilistic, and critical of the future as other answers might be, so here you go.  I think that given the current trends of globalization and interdependence, the world will have a significantly more improved standard of living, particularly of people in undeveloped places like many parts of Africa and Southeast Asia. Interregional cultural mixing will take place due to the increased trade, creating many somewhat unified cultures based on a wide mix of influences from many places. They'll all have a certain homogeneity provided by the influence of American culture that is widely loved and/or forced upon other people. American culture is the modern mainstream version of the old Hellenistic generic culture. It will be what unites the globe. We'll be so deep into our ecological crisis that in many ways, this is going to be the time that a very radical change in global economy works. This will certainly not be our demise, but it will knock all of us flat on our backs for a while. America, with its wasteful, highly capitalized way of life, will be most affected by far. America, despite having such a major unifying influence across the globe, will lose its place as a leader in the economy. It will no longer be a major exporter of agricultural products—not even its vast wealth and power over subordinate nations can buy it out of facing its own consequences. America's spot on the world's list of favorite people won't be lost yet—people world wide will still hold a near universal admiration for Americans, much like how Britain had much prestige while it was a global superpower a century ago. However, America's grip on the world's money will be on the decline and other nations will begin to fill the void america left behind, providing their own agricultural exports, manufacturing, and cultural influences. I'm guessing India will be a likely candidate for spreading its own culture and economic potential, though China will most likely still have a bigger hold on the economy. Africa, though seemingly unlikely right now, will see an enormous growth in every aspect. Its standard of health will dramatically improve thanks to relief efforts from outside as well as public health access improvements within. Armed conflicts will decline as they are doing already, and people will begin to build better lives. Access to education will improve, and we'll start to see African nations will become leaders in innovation and business. Unlike America which grew up in a time when the world was largely unaware that the earth had limits, Africa will grow in a time when environmental impact is a fact of life and will develop much more responsibly and sustainably. During these next fifty years, Africa is setting the stage to become the next successful continent in 100 years, as Europe has done before it(albeit with less colonialism involved.) While the answer to the question of how much power they will have is a mystery, the fact is very clear that they are already making significant advancements and they don't seem to be losing momentum.    I could definitely go on to list more ways I think the world will be like in fifty years, like the rights and social status of different groups in different places, population fluctuations, agriculture, the average standing of the average person, technologies, the state of peace, etc., but I think I'd better stop now. About the only thing I can venture with any degree of surety is that cars will be using one of three powerplant designs:  organic diesel, pure electric, and diesel-electric hybrids.  We're never going to run out of organic waste oils and "grease cars" are already so numerous that city streets are beginning to smell like french fries and egg rolls.  Fuel cells and similar technologies are liable to result in 'self-charging batteries' which will be great for vehicles which don't see constant use.   IC engines beat electric hands-down for sustained (highway) travel while electric motors can't be beat for stop-and-go, low speed (city) travel.  City-use vehicles will lean towards all-electric while general purpose vehicles will favor the diesel-electric hybrid approach which locomotives have been using for decades - just using organic fuels instead of petroleum. If I'm still around, I don't think I'd want to be on the streets around self-driving cars.  There are simply too many bends in the pipe, so to speak, where even a minor glitch can result in catastrophe.  We're already going down a slippery slope with airbags, collision avoidance, and other features which are making people stupid (see Too Safe for Safety’s Sake and the Volvo Effect). All the factors which led to large cities throughout most of human history have been losing their relevance over the past few decades, and we're already seeing a swing back towards "Mid-Town America" - big enough to have good cell phone coverage and high-speed internet, but no skyscrapers.  The Dakotas have already been rebranded as "The Silicon Prairie" because numerous IT firms are taking advantage of empty land and low cost of living.  Why spend $1,000,000 for a one-bedroom flat in Manhattan when $250,000 will buy a four-bedroom manor house in Fargo?  This last is liable to cause a swing towards something similar to 1950s suburbia and the rebirth of The American Dream.
